comments.author: Lucius
comments.body: When you sell something, you should be more precise in some details, because otherwise it can lead to unpleasant situations. For example, here you claim that the account is "unlimited", but you state the following in the shop :Quote*30 days warranty. *account is for one person only. *Do not change account information. *Do not change the password. *Do not add or delete a profile. *Do not ask me refund or back your money read description After buy product. If you break the rules, your warranty will be voided.Which means that after 30 days you can refuse to extend the use of the service for any reason. Also, you are not selling an account here, you are selling the use of one profile within that account, which is a big difference. The price of $10 may be favorable for some, but for the same price I buy a completely legal Premium UHD account and use 4 profiles simultaneously on 4 different devices.In addition, in most countries you can no longer share profiles outside the household if you do not pay extra, or you cannot share them at all.

If you break the rules, your warranty will be voided.This is too good to be true and just unbelievable you mean I'm just paying you $10 and I have a NETFLIX PREMIUM 4K ULTRA HD LIFETIME, Netflix is a monthly subscription I'm paying $11.50 a month to renew my subscription, and yet you are here offering lifetime.According to a Netflix spokesman, there is no such thing as a lifetime subscriptionQuoteNetflix spokesman Cliff Edwards confirmed to Fairfax Media that theres is "no such thing" as a lifetime subscription to Netflix."Consumers should be cautious when offers online promise something that seems too good to be true," Edwards said.'Lifetime' Netflix subscriptions: why buying from scammers isn't worth itConsumers should be warned.
